title: Lmod modules generated for Clang compiled software not different from Core (GCC) built software
body:
In past behavior the modules generated for software compiled using clang would correctly denote this such as `linux-centos7-x86_64/clang` when the core compiler would be specified as some version of GCC. With the most recent version of Spack (tested against a commit form last night) I'm seeing naming conflicts between the modules being generated.

### Error Message

I'm seeing two errors. The first has to do with the creation of the `llvm` module:

```console
$ cat /ecp/sw/dev/ecp-x86_64/modulefiles/nmc/lmod/linux-centos7-x86_64/Core/llvm/7.0.1.lua
-- -*- lua -*-
-- Module file created by spack (https://github.com/spack/spack) on 2019-12-19 09:50:45.730494
...
-- Services provided by the package
family("compiler")

-- Loading this module unlocks the path below unconditionally
prepend_path("MODULEPATH", "/ecp/sw/dev/ecp-x86_64/modulefiles/nmc/lmod/linux-centos7-x86_64/Core")
...
```

In this above example even the module is generated correctly it is trying to prepend the Core module path, which creates a loop and causes Lmod to crash when attempting an `ml avail`. After manually addressing the above issue I'm able to move onto building software using Clang successfully. However, if I attempt to generate the associated modulefiles:

```console
$ spack module lmod refresh
-- linux-centos7-haswell / clang@7.0.1 --------------------------
...
-- linux-centos7-haswell / gcc@4.8.5 ----------------------------
...
-- linux-centos7-haswell / gcc@8.3.0 ----------------------------
...
==> Do you want to proceed? [y/n] y
==> Error: Name clashes detected in module files:

file: /ecp/sw/dev/ecp-x86_64/modulefiles/nmc/lmod/linux-centos7-x86_64/Core/python/2.7.16.lua
spec: python@2.7.16%clang@7.0.1+bz2+ctypes+dbm+lzma~nis~optimizations+pic+pyexpat+pythoncmd+readline+shared+sqlite3+ssl~tix~tkinter~ucs4~uuid+zlib arch=linux-centos7-haswell
spec: python@2.7.16%gcc@4.8.5+bz2+ctypes+dbm+lzma~nis~optimizations+pic+pyexpat+pythoncmd+readline+shared+sqlite3+ssl~tix~tkinter~ucs4~uuid+zlib arch=linux-centos7-haswell

file: /ecp/sw/dev/ecp-x86_64/modulefiles/nmc/lmod/linux-centos7-x86_64/Core/libevent/2.1.8.lua
spec: libevent@2.1.8%clang@7.0.1+openssl arch=linux-centos7-haswell
spec: libevent@2.1.8%gcc@4.8.5+openssl arch=linux-centos7-haswell
...
```

If we examine my `modules.yaml` I have only specified one core compiler:

```yaml
modules:
  enable:
  - lmod

  lmod:
    hierarchy:
      - mpi
      - lapack
    hash_length: 0
    core_compilers: ['gcc@4.8.5']
```

### Information on your system

```console
$ uname -a
Linux xx-fe1.cluster 3.10.0-957.12.2.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue May 14 21:24:32 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

$ cat /etc/os-release
NAME="CentOS Linux"
VERSION="7 (Core)"
ID="centos"
ID_LIKE="rhel fedora"
VERSION_ID="7"
PRETTY_NAME="CentOS Linux 7 (Core)"
```

Environment and lock files for both the compiler deployment as we as software deployed using Clang.

* https://github.com/paulbry/nmc-swd/tree/initial-dev/prod/ecp-x86_64/0-base
* https://github.com/paulbry/nmc-swd/tree/initial-dev/prod/ecp-x86_64/1-core
